required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Oxygen Therapy on Fatigue in Patients With Hypermobile-type Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Oxygen Therapy on Fatigue in Patients With Hypermobile-type Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: a Randomised Double-blind Placebo-controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis of the OXYSED study is that the delivery of 3 months of oxygen therapy via an oxygen concentrator would reduce fatigue, pain, headaches, kinesiophobia, drug intake, dyspnea, and improve walking performance, quality of sleep and quality of life of patients with Ehlers Danlos syndrome hypermobility type (EDS / HT).

secondary_outcome.measure: PRISM (Pictorial Representation of Illness and Self Measure) score
SF-36 quality of life questionnaire (Short Form Heath Survey) score
HADS (Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale) score

secondary_outcome.description: The consumption of care is defined by the presence of at least one major criterion associated or not with the minor criterion: Major criteria: Variation of at least one level in the frequency of use and / or in the duration of use compared to the baseline assessment concerning the use of flexible and / or rigid orthoses, Variation of at least one level of the analgesic levels used compared to the baseline assessment for pain relievers. Variation of at least one level in frequency compared to the baseline assessment for physiotherapy sessions. Minor criterion: Variation of the total daily dose compared to the baseline assessment for painkillers.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of oxygen therapy sessions followed by the patient

intervention.description: oxygen treatment (5 L/minute for 30 minutes by nasal cannula, twice/day)
ambient air not enriched with oxygen (5 L/minute for 30 minutes by nasal cannula, twice/day)
